bibl.title: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, November 8, 1922

div1.p: Frost requests that Carter give two epidemiology lectures on yellow fever at Johns Hopkins University.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, November 8, 1922
div1.opener:
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
Miscl
Lectures
Hopkins
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
310-312 WEST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD.November 8, 1922.
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I am trying this year to establish in
addition to the course in epidemiology which I have
heretofore given, a second course consisting of about
twenty lectures in descriptive epidemiology, and am
writing to ask if you would be willint to undertake
two lectures in the course.

What I am trying to do is to present a
fairly full discussion of the epidemiology of some eight
or ten of the more important infectious diseases, select-
ing at least one from each of the major epidemiological
groups.

I have tentatively allotted two lectures
each to typhoid fever, diphtheria, influenza, tuberculosis,
yellow fever and plague, with one lecture each on small-
pox, scarlet fever, measles and cerebrospinal meningitis;
the remaining hours in the course to be devoted to intro-
ductory and concluding lectures on epidemiological features
in general and some comparisons of the various diseases
discussed.

It has seemed to me essential that the
lectures on the major or type diseases should be given
so far as possible by men who have had rather extensive
personal experience in studying them. In this department,
between Dr. Preeman, Dr. Doull and myself we can take the
lectures on typhoid fever, diphtheria, influenza and most
of the minor subjects, but I am trying to find lecturers
who have a real command of their subjects to give the
lectures on yellow fever, plague and tuberculosis, and as
to yellow fever there is no one but yourself to be
considered.

Provided the course can be organized as
now planned the lectures will be given on Tuesday and
Thursday afternoons from 2 to 3 o'clock, beginning January
2nd and extending to March 13th; and according to my
Dr. Carter
-2-
11-8-22
tentative schedule the lectures on yellow fever, if
we can find a lecturer, will come on February 6th
and 8th.

Would you be willing to give these two lectures
either on the dates suggested or on any other Tuesday
and Thursday which might be more convenient to you? It
is, I know, imposing upon your generosity to ask it, but
I am very anxious to have yellow fever included in the
course because it seems to me one of the most instructive
of all diseases, and am even more anxious to have you
included in it because we can offer nothing else in the
course at all comparable to the discussion which you
would give on yellow fever.

The honorarium which can be offered is very small,
amounting only to $50 for the two lectures, with repayment,
of course, of the travel expense-not enough to represent
any return for the service but all that our very limited
budget will permit.

If you can see your way to agree even tentatively
to help us out to this extent I shall be very glad to
come to see you sometime when I am in Washington, within
the next few weeks, to outline to you somewhat more fully
what I have in mind as to the scope of the course as
a whole and to ask your advice about it.

With cordial regards to yourself and Miss Laura,
and hoping that you can add this to your other burdens
without unduly taxing yourself, I am,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, W. H. Frost. WHP:G
Accepted provisionally
& asked him to comeover
after Novem 24 -(Nov 10/22)
H. R. C.
